newsitem.title: UK: Millwall kicks off capital restructure plan.
newsitem.headline: Millwall kicks off capital restructure plan.

text.p: Cash-strapped Millwall Holdings, the parent of London soccer club Millwall, announced a 10-million stg capital reconstruction programme on Friday which will see the club managed by a new board led by Greek-Cypriot businessman Theo Paphitis.
The company's administrators Buchler Philips said Millwall would raise 5.97 million stg (net of expenses) by placing 640 million shares at one pence per share.
Another 3.36 million stg will be raised from a two-for-one rights issue.
The club -- currently in the English second division -- would eventually be a part of a larger company involved in leisure and event management.

Millwall was floated on the stock market in 1989 at 20 pence a share but the shares were suspended in January this year at four pence after the management called in administrators when the club was unable to pay interest on its 10 million stg debts.
Under the new management plan, Theo Paphitis will replace Peter Mead as chairman. Mead will become vice chairman.
Paphitis, 37, is also the chairman of Ryman and Contessa group of companies and of Movie and Media Sports Plc
From the money raised, 7.25 million stg will be used to pay off debts leaving it with 2.75 million stg for working capital.

"Millwall has been unable to fulfill its true potential because of the heavy burden of debt. This rescue rights issue and the introduction of new management removes this burden and allows Millwall to move forward both on and off the football field," said Peter Mead.
